name: ray.data.read_api.range
signature: ray.data.read_api.range(n: int, *, parallelism: int = -1, concurrency: Optional[int] = None, override_num_blocks: Optional[int] = None) -> ray.data.dataset.Dataset
summary: Creates a :class:`~ray.data.Dataset` from a range of integers [0..n).
desc:
This function allows for easy creation of synthetic datasets for testing or
benchmarking :ref:`Ray Data <data>`.

args.name: n
args.desc: The upper bound of the range of integers.

args.name: parallelism
args.desc: This argument is deprecated. Use ``override_num_blocks`` argument.

args.name: concurrency
args.desc:
The maximum number of Ray tasks to run concurrently. Set this
to control number of tasks to run concurrently. This doesn't change the
total number of tasks run or the total number of output blocks. By default,
concurrency is dynamically decided based on the available resources.

args.name: override_num_blocks
args.desc:
Override the number of output blocks from all read tasks.
By default, the number of output blocks is dynamically decided based on
input data size and available resources. You shouldn't manually set this
value in most cases.

returns: A :class:`~ray.data.Dataset` producing the integers from the range 0 to n.

examples.code:
>>> import ray
>>> ds = ray.data.range(10000)
>>> ds
Dataset(num_rows=10000, schema={id: int64})
>>> ds.map(lambda row: {"id": row["id"] * 2}).take(4)
[{'id': 0}, {'id': 2}, {'id': 4}, {'id': 6}]
